0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Epinephrine Dosing Calculator - Adult
  • Anaphylaxis: (Auto-injector) Inject contents of 0.3-mg prefilled syringe IM or SUBQ; may repeat with an additional auto-injector if severe anaphylaxis persists
  • Anaphylaxis: (Injectable solution) 0.2 to 0.5 mg (0.2 to 0.5 mL of a 1:1000 solution) IM or SUBQ every 5 minutes as needed (guideline dosing) OR 0.2 to 1 mg SUBQ (manufacturer dosing)
  • Anaphylaxis: (IV infusion) 1 mg (1 mL of 1:1000 solution) in 250 mL D5W (4 mcg/mL) and infuse IV at a rate of 1 mcg/min (15 mL/hr) to 10 mcg/min OR epinephrine 1 mg (1 mL of 1:1000 solution in 100 mL of NS (10 mcg/mL)) and infuse IV at an initial rate of 5 to 15 mcg/min (30 to 100 mL/hr) (guideline dosing)
  • Asthma: (injectable solution) 0.2 to 1 mg (0.2 to 1 mL of 1:1000 solution) SUBQ
  • Asthma: (inhalation) start with 1 inhalation (0.22 mg); if symptoms not relieved after at least 1 min, use once more; do not use again for at least 3 hr
  • Blood coagulation disorder: 0.2 to 1 mg (0.2 to 1 mL of 1:1000 solution) subQ or IM
  • Bradyarrhythmia, Acute symptomatic: 2 to 10 mcg/min IV and titrate to response
  • Cardiac arrest: initial, 1 mg IV/INTRAOSSEOUSLY; may be repeated as necessary every 3 to 5 minutes
  • Cardiac arrest: initial, 2 to 2.5 mg ENDOTRACHEAL if IV/INTRAOSSEOUS access is delayed or cannot be established
  • Cardiac arrest - Hypotension, Acute: 0.1 to 0.5 mcg/kg/min IV
  • Congestion of mucosa: (nasal solution) 1:2000, 1:5000, or 1:10,000, apply locally as drops or spray, or with a sterile swab
  • Excessive uterine contraction: 0.2 to 1 mg (0.2 to 1 mL of 1:1000 solution) subQ or IM
  • Gastrointestinal hemorrhage: Administered via a flexible needle injector (Olympus NM-1K) and inserted through the biopsy channel of the endoscope; 0.5 mL aliquots of epinephrine (1:10,000) was injected by multiple punctures into and around the bleeding point until all bleeding was arrested (study dosing).
  • Glaucoma: 1 drop of 0.25% to 2% ophthalmic solution into the conjunctival sac once or twice daily
  • Hypersensitivity reaction: 0.2 to 1 mg (0.2 to 1 mL of 1:1000 solution) SUBQ
  • Local anesthesia; Adjunct: 1:100,000 (0.01 mg/mL) to 1:20,000 (0.05 mg/mL) with local anesthetics
  • Local anesthesia; Adjunct: (intraspinal) 0.2 to 0.4 mg added to anesthetic spinal fluid mixture
  • Local anesthesia; Adjunct - Obstetric procedure: 0.2 mg added to bupivacaine for hyperbaric spinal anesthesia for cesarean section (study dosing)
  • Syncope, Due to complete heart block or carotid sinus hypersensitivity: 0.2 to 1 mg (0.2 to 1 mL of 1:1000 solution) subQ or IM

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Epinephrine Dosing Calculator- Pediatric
  • Anaphylaxis: (Auto-injector) weight 30 kg or greater: Inject contents of 0.3-mg prefilled syringe IM or SUBQ; may repeat with an additional auto-injector if severe anaphylaxis persists
  • Anaphylaxis: (Auto-injector) weight 15 to 30 kg: Inject contents of 0.15-mg prefilled syringe IM or SUBQ; may be repeat with an additional auto-injector if severe anaphylaxis persists
  • Anaphylaxis: (Injectable solution) 0.01 mg/kg, MAX 0.3 mg (0.3 mL of a 1:1000 solution) IM or SUBQ every 5 minutes as needed (guideline dosing) OR 0.01 mg/kg or 0.3 mg/m(2) SUBQ to a MAX of 0.5 mL of a 1:1000 solution (manufacturer dosing)
  • Anaphylaxis: (IV) 0.01 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of a 1:10,000 solution) up to 10 mcg/min IV to a MAX of 0.3 mg (guideline dosing)
  • Asthma: (injectable solution) 0.01 mg/kg (0.01 mL/kg of 1:1000 solution) or 0.3 mg/m(2) (0.3 mL/m(2) of 1:1000 solution) SUBQ to a MAX of 0.5 mL; repeat every 4 hr if required
  • Asthma: (inhalation) (4 years and older) start with 1 inhalation (0.22 mg); if symptoms not relieved after at least 1 min, use once more; do not use again for at least 3 hr
  • Bradyarrhythmia, Acute symptomatic: 0.01 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of a 1:10,000 solution) IV/INTRAOSSEOUSLY; may be repeated every 3 to 5 minutes as needed
  • Bradyarrhythmia, Acute symptomatic: 0.1 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of a 1:1000 solution) ENDOTRACHEAL if IV/INTRAOSSEOUS access is delayed or cannot be established
  • Cardiac arrest: initial, 0.01 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of a 1:10,000 solution) IV/INTRAOSSEOUSLY; may be repeated every 3 to 5 minutes as needed; MAX dose 1 mg
  • Cardiac arrest: (older infants/children) 0.1 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of a 1:1000 solution) ENDOTRACHEAL if IV/INTRAOSSEOUS access is delayed or cannot be established; flush with 5 mL NS and follow with 5 ventilations, may repeat every 3 to 5 minutes; MAX dose 2.5 mg
  • Cardiac arrest: (neonates) 0.03 to 0.1 mg/kg (0.3 to 1 mL/kg of a 1:10,000 solution) ENDOTRACHEAL followed by 1 to 5 mL saline flush depending on the patient size
  • Cardiac arrest - Hypotension, Acute: 0.1 to 1 mcg/kg/min IV/INTRAOSSEOUS and titrate to response
  • Croup: 0.05 mL/kg nebulized racemic epinephrine, up to a maximum of 0.5 mL per dose of a 2.25% solution
  • Hypersensitivity reaction: 0.01 mg/kg (0.01 mL/kg of 1:1000 solution) or 0.3 mg/m(2) SUBQ to a MAX of 0.5 mL

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Anaphylaxis
  • Asthma
  • Blood coagulation disorder
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Congestion of mucosa
  • Excessive uterine contraction
  • Glaucoma
  • Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Local anesthesia; Adjunct
  • Syncope, Due to complete heart block or carotid sinus hypersensitivity
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Bradyarrhythmia, Acute symptomatic
  • Cardiac arrest - Hypotension, Acute
  • Cataract surgery - Mydriasis induction
  • Croup
  • Gastrointestinal hemorrhage
  • Herpes simplex
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Local anesthesia; Adjunct - Obstetric procedure
  • Septic shock
  • Toxicity of drug, Chloroquine
  • Wheezing, In infants

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• cardiac dilatation and coronary insufficiency
  • concurrent use with cyclopropane or halogenated hydrocarbon anesthetic; may sensitize the heart to the arrhythmic action of sympathomimetic drugs
  • concurrent use with local anesthetics for injection of certain areas (eg; fingers, toes, ears); increased risk of vasoconstriction and sloughing of tissue
  • for persons requiring emergency supportive therapy for an anaphylactic reaction, there are no absolute contraindications for the use of epinephrine
  • hypersensitivity to sympathomimetic amines
  • in cases where vasopressor drugs may be contraindicated (eg; thyrotoxicosis, diabetes, in obstetrics when maternal blood pressure is in excess of 130/80 and in hypertension and other cardiovascular disorders); except as diluted for admixture with local anesthetics to reduce absorption and prolong action
  • labor; may delay the second stage
  • narrow-angle (congestive) glaucoma
  • organic brain damage (injection)
  • shock (nonanaphylactic)
  • within 2 weeks of MAOI use

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- avoid larger doses or inadvertent IV injection; increased risk for a sharp increase in blood pressure resulting in cerebral hemorrhage, angina pectoris, or aortic rupture
  • -- preexisting hypertension, cardiac arrhythmias, coronary insufficiency, organic heart disease, ischemic heart disease or concurrent use with drugs that may sensitize the heart to arrhythmias may precipitate or aggravate angina pectoris and produce ventricular arrhythmias
  • -- loss of blood flow may occur with inadvertent injection into the digits, hands, or feet; immediate professional treatment is advised
  • Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- increased risk of adverse effects in patients with preexisting diabetes
  • -- increased risk of adverse effects in patients with hyperthyroidism
  • Immunologic:
  • -- hypersensitivity to sulfites may occur as certain products contain sodium metabisulfite; use epinephrine for anaphylaxis treatment regardless of sulfite allergy
  • -- gas gangrene may occur with IV injection into buttocks
  • Neurologic:
  • -- avoid overdosage or inadvertent intravenous injection; increased risk for a sharp increase in blood pressure resulting in cerebrovascular hemorrhage
  • -- use caution with autonomic dysreflexia, particularly in spinal cord injury (eg, tetraplegics); dose reduction recommended
  • -- symptoms may worsen temporarily in patients with Parkinson's disease
  • Psychiatric:
  • -- use caution in the presence of psychiatric, emotional, or psychoneurotic conditions
  • Reproductive:
  • -- pregnant women are at an increased risk of developing adverse effects
  • Respiratory:
  • -- use caution with long-standing asthma and emphysema with degenerative heart disease
  • -- increased risk for pulmonary edema and death in patients with peripheral constriction and cardiac stimulation
  • Other:
  • -- injection into buttock may not provide effective anaphylaxis treatment; further immediate professional treatment may is advised
  • -- increased risk of adverse effects in elderly patients

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: WHO documentation states insufficient data.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Palpitations
  • Dermatologic:Pale complexion, Sweating
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea and vomiting
  • Neurologic:Asthenia, Dizziness, Headache, Tremor
  • Psychiatric:Anxiety, Apprehension, Restlessness
  • Respiratory:Difficulty breathing
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiac dysrhythmia, Hypertension, acute, Ventricular fibrillation
  • Neurologic:Cerebral hemorrhage
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary edema

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Epinephrine is a sympathomimetic catecholamine that acts on both alpha- and beta-adrenergic receptors. It is the most potent alpha receptor activator. The drug effectively causes vasoconstriction through its effect on alpha-adrenergic receptors to counter vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, which can lead to loss of intravascular fluid volume and hypotension during anaphylactic reactions. It also induces relaxation of the bronchial smooth muscle by acting on beta-adrenergic receptors to alleviate wheezing and dyspnea.

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono:
• Hepatic, other tissues: rapidly inactivated and degraded by enzymes
  • Hepatic: metabolized by MAO and catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT)
  • Metabolites: metadrenaline, sulfate conjugates, and hydroxy derivatives of mandelic acid

3.title: Excretion
3.mono: Renal: (injection), mostly excreted as inactivated compounds; the rest excreted as unchanged or conjugated compounds

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Inhalation
    Use of inhalational form should be discontinued if asthmatic symptoms become worse or are not relieved within 20 minutes.
  • Intramuscular
    • Auto-injector: For single use injection only
    • Auto-injector: Administer into the anterolateral aspect of the thigh, through clothing if needed
    • Auto-injector: Administer IM or subQ; do not give IV or into buttock, digits, hands, or feet
    • Do not administer if solution develops a pinkish color or is otherwise discolored, or if a precipitate is present.
  • Intravenous
    Dilute epinephrine 1 mg (1 mL of 1:1000 solution) in 250 mL D5W (4 mcg/mL) or dilute epinephrine 1 mg (1 mL of 1:1000 solution) in 100 mL of NS (1:100,000)
  • Subcutaneous
    • Auto-injector: For single use only
    • Auto-injector: Administer IM or subQ; do not give IV or into buttock, digits, hands, or feet
    • Auto-injector: Administer into the anterolateral aspect of the thigh, through clothing if needed
    • Do not administer if solution develops a pinkish color or is otherwise discolored, or if a precipitate is present

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• allergic reactions: resolution of hypersensitivity reactions may indicate efficacy
  • intraocular surgery: dilation of the pupils may indicate efficacy
  • hypotension associated with septic shock: decreased blood pressure may indicate efficacy
  • (IM) allergic reaction severity and cardiac effects; during dose titration for anaphylaxis
  • (IV) vital signs; during titration, including invasive arterial blood and central venous pressures
  • (IV) infusion site; frequently, to ensure flowing freely to avoid extravasation

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
SYMPATHOMIMETICS-PARENTERAL
USES: This class of drugs are used to treat hypotension, bradycardia, heart failure, asthma, and anaphylaxis, which includes epinephrine, norepinephrine, dobutamine, dopamine, isoproterenol, terbutaline, and phenylephrine. PHARMACOLOGY: These agents cause stimulation of adrenergic receptors leading to vasoconstriction, increased inotropy and chronotropy. TOXICOLOGY: Primarily from sympathomimetic excess and can either result from vasoconstriction leading to ischemia and hypoxia in end organs, toxic effects from hypertension or hypotension, and cardiac strain from tachycardia. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Uncommon overdose that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. OVERDOSE: Overdoses are typically iatrogenic. Home exposure is generally from accidental injection of epinephrine autoinjectors. These drugs have occasionally been injected as drugs of abuse, although this is rare. MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Tachycardia, nausea, vomiting, hypertension, headache, diaphoresis, and pallor. SEVERE TOXICITY: Seizures, stroke, pulmonary edema, hypotension, cyanosis, myocardial ischemia or infarction, dysrhythmias, acidosis, hypokalemia, and tissue necrosis. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Tachycardia, nausea, vomiting, hypertension, headache, diaphoresis, and pallor. Ischemic necrosis secondary to local vasoconstriction can result from extravasation of sympathomimetic agents including dobutamine, dopamine, epinephrine, metaraminol and norepinephrine. TERBUTALINE: use of terbutaline in pregnant women for the prevention or prolonged treatment (beyond 48 to 72 hours) of preterm labor carries the risk of potentially serious maternal cardiac events (ie, tachycardia, cardiac dysrhythmias, myocardial infarction, hypertension and pulmonary edema) and death.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
SYMPATHOMIMETICS-PARENTERAL
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Accidental digital or intramuscular injections of epinephrine can usually be managed with warm soaks and compresses. Other treatments are not well studied, but injections of phentolamine, use of nitroglycerin paste, and injections of terbutaline have been reported to be successful. Vital signs should be continuously monitored in other parenteral overdoses. Hypertension without evidence of end organ dysfunction should first be treated with benzodiazepines which can reduce adrenergic tone and treat agitation. Sinus tachycardia generally does not require treatment unless there is evidence of end organ dysfunction. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Refractory hypertension or hypertension with evidence of end organ dysfunction should be treated with sodium nitroprusside or phentolamine. Hypotension may develop abruptly following hypertension, so a titratable agent is generally preferred. Hypotension should initially be treated with intravenous fluid boluses. If hypotension persists, a vasopressor such as dopamine or norepinephrine should be used unless they were involved in the overdose. Ventricular tachycardias can be treated with lidocaine or amiodarone, and cardioversion if hemodynamically unstable. If sinus tachycardia results in hemodynamic instability or cardiac strain, a short acting beta-blocker such as esmolol can be used, although care should be used as this may result in unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation. OCULAR EXPOSURE: Ocular exposure has occasionally caused systemic manifestations including transient hypertension, palpitations, tachycardia, ventricular ectopy, chest pain and in one case a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: There is no role for prehospital decontamination of a parenterally administered agent. Irrigate eyes and mucous membranes, and wash skin as appropriate. HOSPITAL: There is no role for decontamination of a parenterally administered agent. Irrigate eyes and mucous membranes, and wash skin as appropriate.
  • Airway management: Patients who are comatose or with altered mental status may need orotracheal intubation and mechanical respiratory support.
  • Antidote: Phentolamine can be administered for intravenous extravasation of sympathomimetic agents. Doses of 5 to 10 mg of phentolamine in 10 to 15 mL of normal saline can be infiltrated into the affected area. Phentolamine has also been reportedly used successfully in accidental subcutaneous epinephrine injections that produce digit ischemia. Doses of 0.5 to 1.5 mg injected either as a digital block or into the same site of the epinephrine injection have been reported. Intra-arterial infusion of phentolamine was used in one patient after inadvertent intra-arterial administration of epinephrine, with apparent success in reversing vasospasm and ischemia.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Hemodialysis is generally not useful since these agents have short half-lives.
  • Monitoring of patient: Drug levels are not clinically useful. Monitor vital signs frequently. Monitor serum electrolytes. Obtain cardiac enzymes for patients with chest pain. Obtain serial ECGs and institute continuous cardiac monitoring. Obtain a chest x-ray if there are signs or symptoms of pulmonary edema. Obtain a chest x-ray if there are signs or symptoms of pulmonary edema.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: Patients with accidental injections of epinephrine autoinjectors can generally be managed at home with warm soaks. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Patients that do not manifest symptoms after 4 to 6 hours can be discharged. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients with unstable vital signs or evidence of end organ dysfunction should be admitted to an intensive care unit. CONSULT CRITERIA: Consult a poison center or medical toxicologist for assistance in managing severe poisonings.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
SYMPATHOMIMETICS-PARENTERAL
TOXICITY: Varies depending on the agent. Toxic effects may occur at therapeutic doses while large doses have also resulted in no ill effects. Also depends on comorbid conditions as myocardial infarction has occurred with doses as little as 0.6 mg SubQ epinephrine. Fatalities have been reported at doses of 3 to 4 mg IV epinephrine. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Varies depending on the agent. Epinephrine is typically given 0.3 mg IM or 1 mg IV to an adult. Norepinephrine is typically started as a drip at 4 mcg/min IV to an adult. Phenylephrine is typically given 2 to 5 mg IM or 0.1 to 0.5 mg IV bolus to an adult.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to periodically inspect epinephrine solution for particulate matter or discoloration. Do not use if particulates or discoloration are noted.
  • This drug may cause palpitations, pale skin, sweating, nausea, vomiting, asthenia, dizziness, headache, tremor, anxiety, apprehension, or nervousness.
  • If used for an anaphylactic reaction, instruct patient to immediately seek medical assistance, even if the patient feels better after epinephrine use.
  • Advise patient on the difference between trainer and actual injector pens.
  • Instruct patient on proper administration technique, depending on formulation used.
